awd_titl_txt: RIDIR:  Longitudinal Intergenerational Family Electronic Micro-Database (LIFE-M)
awd_abstract_narration:
Some of the most important questions in social science and public policy relate to how individuals' lives and experiences have changed across time. However, most data spanning the late 19th and 20th centuries are cross-sectional -- large sets of individuals at one point in time. Cross-sectional data limit the study of economic and geographic mobility, family formation and dissolution, and the long-term impacts of adverse events, public policies, or family background. This proposal seeks to transform vital records data into the Longitudinal, Intergenerational Family Electronic Micro-Database (LIFE-M). LIFE-M comprehensively covers individuals born in the United States from 1880 to 1930, including representative samples of men and women, linking networks of families across up to four generations, and census information with measures of health, family background, and early life context. 

LIFE-M allows for the comprehensive study of the economic and geographic mobility of individuals and families, family formation and dissolution, and the long-term effects of adverse events, public policies, and family resources on economic and family processes. LIFE-M is constructed by linking digitized vita records (birth, death and mortality certificates) with historical records from decennial census. The major advantage of the data assembled is the ability to carry out comprehensive, longitudinal analyses of large samples and subsamples of individuals and families over multiple generations. The LIFE-M database will be made accessible in a user-friendly format for researchers and policy analysts to use. The project is of groundbreaking utility for researchers in demography, geography, sociology, and economics. In addition, the project is of great utility to policy makers and policy analysts interested in the historical context for understanding mobility and demographic change in the United States over the 20th century.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the award was to create the Longitudinal Intergenerational Family Electronic Micro-dataset (LIFE-M)—a longitudinal database spanning the early and middle 20th century, incorporating information from over 185 million individual US vital statistics records and the 1880-1940 Decennial Censuses. LIFE-M’s novel database is accessible in a user-friendly format to facilitate high-impact research on important and unresolved research questions. The LIFE-M data allow researchers to conduct studies of the relationship of early-life circimustances and policies on health and longevity.

During the project period, we worked relentlessly to create the LIFE-M database by (1) systematically hand linking records for training machine-learning models; (2) refining and developing new linking methods for different linking types; and (3) implementing cutting-edge computational methods to link records on a very large scale. In January 2022, we (4) released the data for public use along with extensive documentation. The LIFE-M data have been released via an Open ICPSR with all meta information and documentation (https://www.openicpsr.org/openicpsr/project/155186) as well as on the website, http://www.life-m.org.

In addition, LIFE-M has broader impacts, including on other on-going linkage efforts at the Census Bureau and the Minnesota Population Center. For instance, LIFE-M helps inform, extend, and improve the Census Bureau’s new Core Longitudinal Infrastructure Population Project (CLIPP), which aims to combine census data including administrative records and population records. IPUMS USA published a variable, LNKLIFEM, which allows researchers to connect the LIFE-M data with the full-count IPUMS census data, enhancing both data sources.  


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Martha J Bailey
